title: Palindromes Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of words and phrases that read the same forwards and backwards!

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Level' is a palindrome â€” it reads the same forwards (L-E-V-E-L) and backwards (L-E-V-E-L). It is one of the most common palindromes in everyday English.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Noon' reads the same forwards and backwards: N-O-O-N. It has been a palindrome since Old English, derived from the Latin 'nona hora' (ninth hour).

questions.question: Which of these is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Racecar' is a famous palindrome: R-A-C-E-C-A-R reads the same forwards and backwards. It is one of the longest common single-word palindromes.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: Both 'Dad' (D-A-D) and 'Mom' (M-O-M) are palindromes! These familiar family words read the same forwards and backwards.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Kayak' is a palindrome: K-A-Y-A-K. The word comes from the Inuit language and refers to a small, narrow watercraft.

questions.question: Which famous palindrome phrase is attributed (probably falsely) to Napoleon?
options: "Was it a car or a cat I saw?"
"Able was I ere I saw Elba"
"A man, a plan, a canal: Panama"
questions.explanation: "Able was I ere I saw Elba" is a famous palindrome attributed to Napoleon, referring to his exile to the island of Elba. While he almost certainly never said it, it perfectly captures his story.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Refer' is a palindrome: R-E-F-E-R reads the same forwards and backwards. It comes from the Latin 'referre' meaning to carry back.

questions.question: Which of these is a palindromic phrase (ignoring spaces and punctuation)?
options: "Was it a car or a cat I saw"
questions.explanation: "Was it a car or a cat I saw" is a palindrome when you ignore spaces and punctuation: wasitacaroracatisaw reads the same in both directions.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Civic' is a palindrome: C-I-V-I-C reads the same forwards and backwards. It comes from the Latin 'civicus,' relating to a citizen or city.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Rotor' is a palindrome: R-O-T-O-R. It refers to a rotating part of a machine, and the word itself rotates perfectly in spelling!

questions.question: Which famous palindrome relates to the construction of a waterway?
options: "Go hang a salami, I'm a lasagna hog"
"A man, a plan, a canal: Panama"
questions.explanation: "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama" is one of the most famous palindromes in English, referring to the building of the Panama Canal. It was coined by Leigh Mercer in 1948.

questions.question: Which of these words is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Deified' is a palindrome: D-E-I-F-I-E-D. Meaning 'made into a god,' it is one of the longest common English palindromes at seven letters.

questions.question: What is the term for a number that reads the same forwards and backwards (like 12321)?
questions.explanation: A palindromic number reads the same forwards and backwards, just like a word palindrome. Examples include 11, 121, 1331, and 12321.

questions.question: Which of these is a palindrome?
questions.explanation: 'Reviver' is a palindrome: R-E-V-I-V-E-R. At seven letters, it is one of the longest common English word palindromes, meaning one who revives.

questions.question: What is the longest single-word palindrome commonly found in English dictionaries?
questions.explanation: 'Redivider' (one who redivides) at nine letters is often cited as the longest common single-word palindrome in English: R-E-D-I-V-I-D-E-R.
